Although the invention is described herein with certain ones of the connection posts 207, 330, 420 entering into and nesting within others, the invention is not to be limited by the exact interaction illustrated and described herein.

In other embodiments, distal ends of the connection posts 207, 330, 420 may interact to couple the components together or the like. Thus, variations to that which is described herein may be possible in certain alternative embodiments and such variations and modifications would be readily apparent to persons skilled in the art.

Referring to FIGS. 1 and 2, the apparatus 100 is illustrated in a fully assembled state with the drip tray 400 coupled to the second housing assembly 300 and the first housing assembly 200 coupled to the drip tray 400. When so assembled, the outer surface 322 of the second housing assembly 300 is flush with the outer surface 405 of the drip tray 400. Thus, the outer surfaces 322, 405 of the second housing assembly 300 and the drip tray 400 are seamless and flush at their interface to give the apparatus 100 a clean appearance. In some embodiments, a bottom surface of the drip tray 400 may be in surface contact with the top surface 321 of the second housing assembly 300, such as depicted in FIG. 2.

However, when the first housing assembly 200 is coupled to the drip tray 400, an upper edge of the drip tray 400 (i.e., the distal end 407 of the sidewall 403 of the drip tray 400) is spaced apart from the bottom end 204 of the first housing assembly 200 by an annular air gap 199. This allows air to enter into the first housing assembly 200 from the bottom end 204 of the first housing assembly 200 when the fan device 210 is rotating. Thus, when the fan device 210 is rotating, the fan device 210 pulls air into the first housing assembly 200 through the annular air gap 199 so that the air stream that generates the bubbles can be generated. Of course, the invention is not to be so limited in all embodiments. In other embodiments, the first housing assembly 200 could be flush with the drip tray 400 when coupled thereto, and the first housing assembly 200 could have air openings that facilitate the entry of air into the first housing assembly 200 for the generation of the air stream as described herein.

Referring to FIGS. 17-19C, the operation of the apparatus 100 to generate bubbles from a bubble solution will be described. As shown in FIG. 17, first the apparatus 100 is assembled as described previously by attaching the drip tray 400 to the second housing assembly 300 and then attaching the first housing assembly 200 to the drip tray 400. There are no fasteners used to couple these components together. Rather, they merely rest one on top of the other and are held in place due to gravity. The alignment features described above may assist in properly orienting the first and second housing assemblies 200, 300 and the drip tray 400 relative to one another, although the alignment features may also be omitted in some embodiments.

Next, a bubble solution bottle 500 is provided. The bubble solution bottle 500 may be any container or the like having a cavity that is configured to hold and store an amount of a bubble solution. The bubble solution bottle 500 may have an open top end 502 that allows for the bubble solution in the bubble solution bottle 500 to be dispensed therefrom. The bubble solution bottle 500 may have a cap 501 thereon that closes the open top end 502 of the bubble solution bottle 500. The cap 501 may be coupled to the bubble solution bottle 500 with a hinge, with mating screw threads, interference fit, snap-fit, or in any other desired manner. To begin use of the apparatus 100, the bubble solution bottle 500 is oriented upside-down and placed so that the open top end 502 faces the storage reservoir 253 of the bubble solution dispenser 250. The support member 270 of the apparatus 100 may hold and retain the bubble solution bottle 500 in the upside-down orientation as shown in FIG. 17.

Referring sequentially to FIGS. 18A-18C concurrently with FIGS. 19A-19C, the operation will be further described. FIG. 19A is a schematic cross-sectional view associated with the relative positioning of the components depicted in FIG. 18A, FIG. 19B is a schematic cross-sectional view associated with the relative positioning of the components depicted in FIG. 18B, and FIG. 19C is a schematic cross-sectional view associated with the relative positioning of the components depicted in FIG. 18C.

Once the bubble solution bottle 500 is coupled to the apparatus 100 in its upside-down orientation, the bubble solution will flow out of the bubble solution bottle 500 and into the storage reservoir 253 of the hub portion 251 of the bubble solution dispenser 250. The bubble solution will flow into both of the first and second portions 257, 258 of the storage reservoir 253. However, without activating the apparatus 100 by pressing the actuator 309, in some embodiments the bubble solution will not flow to the deliver reservoir 352 of the delivery member 252. Thus, the bubble solution will not flow from the bottle 500 to the delivery reservoir 352 unless the bubble solution dispenser 250 is being moved by the motor 302. This is due to the ramping of the floor 254 of the second circumferential portion 262 of the storage reservoir 253 as described above and best depicted in FIGS. 19A-19C. Thus, until a user presses the actuator 309 to power the motor 302, the bubble solution will not flow to the delivery reservoir 352 and will therefore not be delivered onto the bubble generating apparatus 240. This may be preferable because otherwise the bubble solution would begin to drip downwardly from the delivery member 252 before the bubble solution dispenser 250 is rotating, which will likely result in much of that bubble solution simply dripping down to the drip tray 400 rather than being used to load the bubble generating devices 241. However, in other embodiments as noted above the ramped portion may be omitted so that upon the bubble solution bottle 500 being placed in the upside-down orientation as shown, the bubble solution will flow all the way to the delivery reservoir 352 for delivery to the bubble generating devices 241 of the bubble generating assembly 240.

As seen in FIGS. 18A and 19A, the paddles 290 are each supported from above by one of the arm members 273 of the support member 270. In the exemplified embodiment, the paddles 290 are formed from a resilient material, such as for example an elastomeric material, a rubber, a thermoplastic elastomer, or the like. The paddles 290 may also be formed of other resilient materials, including a flexible plastic, so long as the paddles 290 are configured to operate/function as described herein. An upper portion 291 of each of the paddles 290 is fixed to one of the arm members 273 and a lower portion of each of the paddles 290 hangs downwardly from the arm member 273 without being physically coupled to any other structure. Thus, the paddles 290 are suspended by the arm members 273 within the second portion 258 of the storage reservoir 253 of the hub portion 251 of the bubble solution dispenser 250. In other words, the paddles 290 are suspended from the arm members 273 in a cantilevered manner.

The support member 270 is fixed to the first housing assembly 200 so as to be static or non-movable relative to the first housing assembly 200. Thus, the paddles 290 are also in a fixed position relative to the first housing assembly 200 due to their being coupled directly to one of the arm members 273 of the support member 270. In the exemplified embodiment, the paddles 290 do not rotate during operation but rather they remain fixed as the bubble solution dispenser 250 rotates as described herein. Thus, the location of the paddles 290 within the bubble solution dispenser 250 changes, but only due to the rotation of the bubble solution dispenser 250 and not due to any movement of the paddles 290. Of course, in other embodiments the paddles 290 and the bubble generating assembly 240 may rotate while the bubble solution dispenser 250 stays static, in other embodiments the paddles 290 and the bubble solution dispenser 250 may rotate in opposite rotational directions while the bubble generating assembly 240 remains static, and in other embodiments the paddles 290 may rotate while the bubble solution dispenser 250 and the bubble generating assembly 240 remain static. Thus, there are variations that are possible in terms of which component is moving/rotating in alternative embodiments while still enabling the apparatus to function as described herein. However, the paddles 290 and the bubble solution dispenser 250 should move or rotate relative to one another to facilitate movement of the bubble solution to the delivery reservoir 352 as described herein.

Although the paddles 290 are described as being in a fixed position in the exemplified embodiment and being static relative to the first housing assembly 200, it should be appreciated that the paddles 290 are able to flex and move as the apparatus 100 is operating. This is because only the upper portions 291 of the paddles 290 are affixed to the support member 270 with the lower portions 292 of the paddles 290 hanging freely below the support arms 273 within the second portion 258 of the storage reservoir 253. This allows the lower portions 292 of the paddles 290 to flex or move relative to the upper portions 291 of the paddles 290 as the paddles 290 contact the bubble solution in the storage reservoir 253 or the floor 254 of the storage reservoir 253 (as shown in FIGS. 19A-19C).

Referring collectively to FIGS. 18A-19C, during operation the motor 302 rotates, which causes the fan device 210 to rotate and generate an air stream and also causes the bubble solution dispenser 250 to rotate. In some embodiments, the bubble solution dispenser 250 may rotate in a clockwise direction (as shown in the exemplified embodiment), but the invention is not to be so limited and the bubble solution dispenser 250 could alternatively rotate in a counter-clockwise direction. As the bubble solution dispenser 250 rotates, the paddles 290 contact the bubble solution located in the second portion 258 of the storage reservoir 253. The bubble solution is unable to flow up the second circumferential portion 262 of the second portion 258 of the storage reservoir 253 due to its ramped configuration. However, as the bubble solution dispenser 250 rotates, the paddles 290 contact the bubble solution and move (or drive) it upwardly along the second circumferential portion 262 of the second portion 258 of the storage reservoir 253 (see FIG. 19B).

Eventually, the paddles 290 drive or otherwise move the bubble solution to the terminal end 263 of the second circumferential portion 262 of the floor 254 of the second portion 258 of the storage reservoir 253. At such time, the bubble solution flows into the dispensing portion 265 of the storage reservoir 253 that is located between the stopper wall 264 and the terminal end 263 of the second circumferential portion 262 of the floor 254 of the second portion 258 of the storage reservoir 253. From the dispensing portion 265, the bubble solution readily flows through the opening 269 in the second annular sidewall 256 to the delivery reservoir 352.

Once in the delivery reservoir 352, the bubble solution flows out through the apertures 354 and either: (1) onto one of the bubble generating devices 241 of the bubble generating assembly 240; or (2) into the drip tray 400.

As noted above, during operation the bubble solution dispenser 250 is rotating about the rotational axis R1-R1. As the bubble solution dispenser 250 rotates, the delivery member 252 passes across different ones of the bubble generating devices 241. The delivery member 252 passes over the top of the bubble generating devices 241 in the exemplified embodiment, although the delivery member 252 could pass beneath the bubble generating devices 241 in other embodiments as described above. Furthermore, the bubble solution located in the delivery reservoir 352 of the delivery member 252 of the bubble solution dispenser 350 continuously drips out through the apertures 354. Thus, as the bubble solution dispenser 250 rotates, the bubble solution dispenser 250 dispenses the bubble solution onto each of the bubble generating devices 241 in succession. The process continues because as the bubble solution dispenser 250 rotates, the paddles 290 continue to drive or otherwise move the bubble solution into the dispensing portion 265 of the storage reservoir 253, from where the bubble solution flows into the delivery reservoir 352 for delivery onto the different bubble generating devices 241.

As noted above, the bubble generating devices 241 of the bubble generating assembly 240 are positioned so as to be aligned with the air stream generated by the fan device 210. As the air stream generated by the fan device 210 passes the bubble generating devices 241 that are loaded with the bubble solution, bubbles are formed as depicted in FIGS. 18A-18C. Then, the bubble solution dispenser 250 will dispense an additional amount of the bubble solution onto the bubble generating devices 241 and the process continues indefinitely until either the power source 301 runs out of power, the user powers the device off (by activating the actuator 309 a second time), or the bubble solution bottle 500 and the storage reservoir 253 becomes depleted of bubble solution.

After use, a user can power the apparatus 100 off by activating the actuator 309. Next, the user detaches the first housing assembly 200 from the drip tray 400. The first housing assembly 200 can then be washed under a sink faucet or hose as may be desired. The first housing assembly 200 does not contain or otherwise include any electronic components so washing or rinsing the first housing assembly 200 does not harm its functionality. Next, the drip tray 400 is carefully detached from the second housing assembly 200. Once detached, a user can pour the bubble solution that was collected in the drip tray 400 back into the bubble solution bottle 500 or into another desired location. The drip tray 400 can then also be washed or rinsed under water. Finally, a user can wipe off the second housing assembly 200. The user may not want to wash or rinse the second housing assembly 200 because it contains all of the electronics for the apparatus 100. However, the second housing assembly 200 can be satisfactorily cleaned by wiping it with a dry or damp cloth, towel, or the like. The second housing assembly 300 is generally kept away from the bubble solution during use because the bubble solution is only intended to contact the first housing assembly 200 and the drip tray 400 and thus there should not be much bubble solution to clean off of the second housing assembly 300 after use. The apparatus 100 may then be set aside and stored either as separate components in the disassembled state or in the assembled state after being reassembled.

Referring to FIGS. 20-23, an apparatus for generating bubbles 1000 (hereinafter referred to as the apparatus 1000) will be described. The apparatus 1000 may also be referred to herein as a bubble generating machine. The apparatus 1000 is designed to generate bubbles from a bubble solution in an automatic fashion by way of moving parts that are operably coupled to a motor. Thus, a bubble solution may be dispensed onto bubble generating devices and then bubbles can be generated from the bubble solution loaded on the bubble generating devices as an air stream flows through the bubble generating devices. In some embodiments, there are no pumps, valves, or other similar types of devices included for facilitating movement of the bubble solution to the bubble generating devices. Thus, the apparatus 1000 may be devoid of any pumps in some embodiments. Furthermore, in some embodiments a user need not actuate a switch or the like to power on the apparatus 1000. Rather, in some embodiments when a container of bubble solution is held by the apparatus 1000 in an upside down orientation so that the bubble solution is dispensed from the container into the apparatus 1000, the apparatus 1000 is automatically powered on. The details of this functionality will be described in greater detail below.

The apparatus 1000 comprises a housing 1100 extending along a longitudinal axis D-D and a drip tray 1200 that is detachably coupled to the housing 1100. As will be discussed in greater detail below, excess amounts of the bubble solution that are dispensed from the apparatus 1000 but not loaded onto a bubble generating device will be collected in a collection trough 1201 of the drip tray 1200. The excess bubble solution that is collected in the collection trough 1201 can later be poured back into a container for reuse. By having the housing 1100 detachable from the drip tray 1200, the drip tray 1200 can be easily lifted up and tilted to pour the collected excess bubble solution back into a container.

The drip tray 1200 comprises a floor 1202, an outer wall 1203 protruding from the floor 1202 along an outer edge of the floor 1202, and a drainage member 1204 protruding from the floor 1202 in a spaced apart manner from the outer wall 1203 so that the outer wall 1203 surrounds the drainage member 1204. The space between the inner surface of the outer wall 203 and the outer surface of the drainage member 1204 forms the collection trough 1201. The collection trough 1201 has an open top end so that any bubble solution or other fluid collected therein can be readily seen by a user. In this way, a user will readily know when the collection trough 1201 is becoming full so that the user can shut down the apparatus 1000 to pour the bubble solution from the collection trough 1201 back into a container.

The drainage member 1204 extends from the floor 1202 to a distal surface 1205. In the exemplified embodiment, the drainage member 1204 is not centered along the floor 1202 of the drip tray 1200. Rather, the drainage member 1204 is offset from a centerpoint of the floor 1202 of the drip tray 1200. As a result, the housing 1100 does not block visual access to the collection trough 1201. Rather, a user could look down onto the apparatus 1000 from above and some of the collection trough 1201 would be visible. Thus, a line of sight exists from a top of the apparatus 1000 to the collection trough 1201 from a top plan view. Stated another way, the drip tray 1200 and the housing 1100 have different footprints which permits ready user visualization of any fluids collected in the collection trough. The drip tray 1200 comprises a pour spout 1209 along the outer wall 1203 to allow for easy pouring of the bubble solution collected in the collection trough 1201 back into a container or the like.

Furthermore, the drainage member 1204 comprises a plurality of connection members 1206 extending from the distal surface 1205 in a spaced apart manner. In the exemplified embodiment, the connection members 1206 are arranged circumferentially around the outer surface of the drainage member 1204 and protrude upwardly away from the distal surface 1205. Furthermore, in the exemplified embodiment each of the connection members 1206 defines a receiving cavity for receiving a component of the housing 1100 to couple the housing 1100 to the drip tray 1200, as described in greater detail below.

In the exemplified embodiment, the drainage member 1204 has a plurality of inclined drainage surface 1207 in the space between each pair of adjacent connection members 1206. Specifically, the outer surface of the drainage member 1204 is sloped between the adjacent connection members 1206 to facilitate the flow of any excess amounts of the bubble solution down the inclined drainage surfaces 1207 and into the collection trough 1201. The inclined drainage surfaces 1207 are inclined in a downward direction from the distal surface 1205 of the drainage member 1204 towards the collection trough 1201.

The housing 1100 comprises an outer annular wall 1101 having an outer surface 1102 that forms an exposed outer surface of the housing 1100 and an inner surface 1103 that surrounds or defines an internal cavity 1104 of the housing 1100. A lower portion of the outer annular wall 1101 terminates in a plurality of circumferentially spaced apart connection members 1105 that are configured to engage or otherwise interact with the connection members 1206 of the drip tray 1200 to couple the housing 1100 to the drip tray 1200. In the exemplified embodiment, the connection members 1105 are protuberances that are received within the receiving cavities of the connection members 1206 of the drip tray 1200. Of course, in alternative embodiments an opposite arrangement could be used whereby the connection members 1206 of the drip tray 1200 are received within cavities of the connection members 1105 of the housing 1100. Moreover, other structures and modifications could be used in other embodiment so long as it facilitates a detachable coupling between the housing 1100 and the drip tray 1200.

In the exemplified embodiment, the coupling of the connection members 1105 of the housing 1100 to the connection members 1206 of the drip tray 1200 creates an interference fit or a frictional fit to couple the housing 1100 to the drip tray 1200. The interference fit should be sufficiently snug and tight so that a user can lift the apparatus 1000 by gripping only the housing 1100 such that the drip tray 1200 remains coupled to the housing 1100. In other embodiments, fasteners such as screws, bolts, or the like could be used to facilitate the coupling of the housing 1100 to the drip tray 1200. However, the friction fit may be desirable in some embodiments because it allows for an easy detachment of the housing 1100 from the drip tray 1200 for cleaning and to pour any bubble solution collected in the collection trough 1201 back into a container or bottle for storage or re-use. In other embodiments, the connection members may be located along the longitudinal axis D-D rather than circumferentially surrounding the longitudinal axis D-D as with the exemplified embodiment. Various permutations and modifications to the connection members 1105, 1206 may be possible in alternative embodiments.

When the housing 1100 is coupled to the drip tray 1200 in the manner described herein, a plurality of air inlet openings 1106 are formed in the spaces between the connection members 1105, 1206. The air inlet openings 1106 allow for ambient air to be pulled into the internal cavity 1104 of the housing 1100 for purposes of generating an air stream that can be used to generate bubbles from the bubble solution loaded on the bubble generating devices. In the exemplified embodiment, each of the air inlet openings 1106 is a closed-geometry shaped opening (more specifically, oval in the exemplified embodiment although any other shape could be formed) that is bounded by an edge of two adjacent ones of the connection members 1105 of the housing 1100 and an edge of two adjacent ones of the connection members 1206 of the drip tray 1200. Thus, the edges of the connection members 1105, 1206 define the air inlet openings 1106. The inclined drainage surfaces 1207 are located along or adjacent to a bottom of each of the air inlet openings 1106 such that the excess fluid can flow through the air inlet openings 1106 and down along the inclined drainage surfaces 1207 to the collection trough 1201 of the drip tray 1200.

The apparatus 1000 further comprises a motor 1300 positioned in the internal cavity 1104 of the housing 1100, a fan device 1310 operably coupled to the motor 1300 so that the motor can rotate the fan device 1310 to generate an air stream, a bubble generating assembly 1320 comprising at least one, and more specifically a plurality of bubble generating devices 1321, a bubble solution dispenser 1400 that dispenses the bubble solution onto the bubble generating devices 1321, and a support member 1450 for supporting a container 1500 containing a store of bubble solution 1501 therein. In the exemplified embodiment, the apparatus 1000 also comprises a power source 1550, which in the exemplified embodiment comprises a plurality of batteries. In other embodiments, the apparatus 1000 may include a power cord that is configured to be plugged into a wall socket to supply power to the electronic devices of the apparatus 1000. Furthermore, other types of power sources can be used and the invention is not limited to batteries and AC power from a socket as noted herein. In the exemplified embodiment, the apparatus also comprises a screen member 1600 positioned to prevent a user from placing fingers or the like into contact with the fan device 1310 particularly while it is operating and spinning at high speeds. In the exemplified embodiment, the screen member 1600 is positioned between the fan device 1310 and the dip tray 1200 so that even if a user is able to extend his/her fingers through the air inlet openings 1106, the user will not be able to contact the fan device 1310.

The fan device 1310 comprises a hub portion 1311 and a plurality of blades 1312 extending outwardly from the hub portion 1311 to generate an air stream when the fan device 1310 is rotated. In the exemplified embodiment, the fan device 1310 comprises three of the blades 1312, although more or less blades could be used in other embodiments. Moreover, it should be appreciated that the fan device 1310 is not limited to being a fan in all embodiments, but can be any device that is configured to generate an air stream when it is powered on. Thus, the fan device 1310 may be any type of air generator, air flow generator, air stream generator, or the like. In the exemplified embodiment, the fan device 1310 is coupled to a first shaft 1301 of the motor 1300. In the exemplified embodiment, the fan device 1310 is coupled directly to the motor 1300 with no intervening gears or the like. Thus, the fan device 1310 will rotate at the same rotational speed (rotations per minute) as the motor 1300. This ensures that a sufficiently viable air stream is generated by the fan device 1310 to ensure that it is capable of generating bubbles from the bubble solution 1501 loaded onto the bubble generating devices 1321 of the bubble generating assembly 1320. Of course, in other embodiments gears may be coupled to the fan device 1310 and the motor 1300 to either speed up or slow down the rotational speed (e.g., revolutions per minute) of the fan device 1310 as compared to the rotational speed of the motor 300.

The bubble generating assembly 1320 comprises a plurality of the bubble generating devices 1321 as noted above. Specifically, in the exemplified embodiment the bubble generating assembly 1320 comprises a hub portion 1322, a plurality of arms 1323 extending radially from the hub portion 1322 in a spaced apart manner, and the plurality of bubble generating devices 1321 each coupled to an end of one of the arms 1323. In the exemplified embodiment, each of the bubble generating devices 1321 is an annular-shaped structure having an inner surface 1324 that surrounds a central aperture 1325. Furthermore, the bubble generating devices 1321 comprise a plurality of ribs or ridges 1326 protruding from the inner surface 1324 in a spaced apart manner. The ridges 1326 assist in loading bubble solution onto the bubble generating devices 1321. Specifically, when a bubble solution is dripped onto the bubble generating devices 1321 or the bubble generating devices 1321 are dipped into a reservoir of bubble solution, the bubble solution adheres to the bubble generating devices 1321 along the ridges 1326 on the inner surface 1324. The bubble solution will then extend across the central aperture 1325, thereby forming a film of the bubble solution that fills in the space defined by the inner surface 1324 of the bubble generating devices 1321. When the bubble solution adheres to the bubble generating devices 1321, those bubble generating devices 1321 are considered to be loaded with the bubble solution.

In the exemplified embodiment, the bubble generating assembly 1320 is operably coupled to a second shaft 1302 of the motor 1300. Thus, in the exemplified embodiment the bubble generating assembly 1320 rotates about a rotational axis during use of the apparatus 1000. However, in other embodiments the bubble generating assembly 1320 may be static/fixed rather than rotating and other features may rotate (specifically, the bubble solution dispenser 1400) to ensure that the bubble generating devices 1321 become loaded with the bubble solution. Turning back to the exemplified embodiment, the bubble generating assembly 1321 is indirectly coupled to the motor 1300 by a gear assembly 1330. The gear assembly 1330 is designed to slow down the rotational speed of the bubble generating assembly 1320 relative to the motor 1300 so that the bubble generating assembly 1320 rotates at a slower rotational speed than the motor 1300. Thus, the gear assembly 1330 operates as a speed reducer such that the output gear (the gear furthest from the motor 1302) rotates more slowly than the input gear (the gear closest to the motor 1300). The exact configuration and arrangement of the gear assembly 1330 including the number and size of the gears thereof, is not to be limiting of the invention in all embodiments.

It should be appreciated that in the exemplified embodiment the motor 1300 controls the movement/rotation of both the fan device 1310 and the bubble generating assembly 1320. In other embodiments, there may be separate motors for controlling rotation of the fan device 1310 and the bubble generating assembly 1320. In still other embodiments, the motor 1300 may control rotation of the fan device 1310 but the bubble generating assembly 1320 may not rotate. Thus, various modifications to the exemplary embodiment exist and may fall within the scope of the claimed invention. In the exemplified embodiment, it should be appreciated that the rotational axis of the bubble generating assembly 1320, the rotational axis of the motor 1300, and the rotational axis of the fan device 1310 are all the same as one another as the same as the longitudinal axis D-D of the housing 1100.

Referring to FIGS. 20-22 and 24, the bubble solution dispenser 1400 and the support member 1450 will be further described. The bubble solution dispenser 1400 comprises a main body portion 1401 and at least one delivery member 1410. In the exemplified embodiment, the main body portion 1401 comprises a floor 1402 and a sidewall 1403 extending upwardly from the floor 1402 so that the floor 1402 and the sidewall 1403 collectively define a holding reservoir 1404. The holding reservoir 1404 is generally sized and shaped so as to be able to hold a container of bubble solution therein in an upside-down orientation so that the bubble solution contained in the container can be poured into the holding reservoir 1404. FIG. 24 illustrates the container 1500 of bubble solution positioned in the holding reservoir 1404 in the upside-down orientation.

The at least one delivery member 1410 extends from the main body portion 1401 and into or at least into alignment with the interior cavity 1104 of the housing 1100. Thus, the at least one delivery member 1410 is suspended or cantilevered over the bubble generating devices 1321 of the bubble generating assembly 1320. Thus, as the bubble generating assembly 1320 rotates, the bubble generating devices 1321 thereof become aligned with the delivery member 1410 one at a time so that they can become loaded with the bubble solution as described herein. The at least one delivery member 1410 comprises a floor 1411 and a sidewall 1412 extending upwardly from the floor 1411 so that the floor 1411 and the sidewall 1412 collectively define a delivery reservoir 1413. The at least one delivery member 1410 comprises at least one slit 1414 (or opening) therein so that bubble solution can fall through the slit for delivery onto the bubble generating devices 1321.

The delivery reservoir 1413 is in fluid communication with the holding reservoir 1404 so that fluid (such as the bubble solution) in the holding reservoir 1404 will flow to the delivery reservoir 1413 where it is eventually dispensed or delivered through the slit 1414 and onto the bubble generating devices 1321 of the bubble generating assembly 1320 as noted above. As described in greater detail below, as the bubble generating assembly 1320 is rotated by the motor 1300, the bubble generating devices 1321 become aligned with and positioned just beneath the delivery member 1410 of the bubble solution dispenser 1400. Furthermore, the bubble solution continuously falls through the slit 1414 so that the at least one delivery member 1410 drops the bubble solution onto the bubble generating devices 1321 as they rotate past the delivery member 1410 to load the bubble generating devices 1321 with the bubble solution. As the bubble generating assembly 1320 continues to be rotated by the motor 1300, the bubble generating devices 1321 become aligned with the air stream generated by the fan device 1310 so that the bubble solution loaded onto the bubble generating devices 1321 is converted into bubbles.

Referring to FIGS. 20, 21, and 24, additional structural details of the housing 1100 will be provided. The housing 1100 comprises the outer annular wall 1101 as previously noted, with the inner surface 1103 of the outer annular wall 1101 defining the interior cavity 1104. In the exemplified embodiment, the motor 1300, the fan device 1310, the bubble generating device 1320, and the gear assembly 1330 are all positioned within the interior cavity 1104 of the housing 1100. However, in other embodiments one or more of these components may be located external of the interior cavity 1104 of the housing 1100. The power source 1550 may be positioned within the housing 1100 or external to it in various different embodiments.

The housing 1100 also comprises a first inner annular wall 1120 that is spaced radially inward of the outer annular wall 1101 and a second inner annular wall 1130 that is spaced radially inward of the first inner annular wall 1120. The first and second inner annular walls 1120, 1130 are connected to one another by a plurality of circumferentially spaced apart fins 1115 for structural rigidity and for managing airflow and reducing turbulence with regard to the air stream generated by the fan device 1310. The space between the first and second inner annular walls 1120, 1130 forms an air flow passageway 1125 through which the air stream generated by the fan device 1310 flows. The air flow passageway 1125 is essentially the only opening that leads from the fan device 1310 upward so substantially all (i.e., 95% or more) of the air stream generated by the fan device 1310 is forced through the air flow passageway 1125. The air flow passageway 1125 is an annular passageway that surrounds the longitudinal axis D-D of the housing 1100. However, in the exemplified embodiment the air flow passageway 1125 does not extend a full 360° around the longitudinal axis D-D. Rather, the air flow passageway 1125 extends approximately between 180° and 300°, more specifically between 180° and 280°, more specifically between 180° and 250° around the longitudinal axis D-D with the remainder being a closed space that facilitates flow of excess fluid into the collection trough 1201 as described in greater detail below. The air stream generated by the fan device 1310 generally flows upward through the air flow passageway 1125 and through the central apertures 1325 of the bubble generating devices 1321. Thus, as best seen in FIG. 25, the central apertures of the bubble generating devices 1321 are aligned with the air flow passageway 1125 and remain aligned with the air flow passageway 1125 as the bubble generating assembly 1320 rotates about the rotational axis as described herein.

The space between the first inner annular wall 1120 and the outer annular wall 1101 forms an excess fluid passageway 1126 through which excess amounts of the bubble solution can flow into the collection trough 1201 of the drip tray 1200. The first inner annular wall 1120 is attached to the outer annular wall 1101 along a bottom edge of the first inner annular wall 1120 to form a floor 1127 of the excess fluid passageway 1126. Furthermore, a plurality of openings 1128 are formed into the floor 1127 of the excess fluid passageway 1126 so that the excess bubble solution can flow therethrough and into the collection trough 1201. The openings 1128 are circumferentially spaced apart in the exemplified embodiment, but could be a single elongated opening in other embodiments so long as an opening exists for the excess bubble solution to flow out of the excess fluid passageway 1126 and into the collection trough 1201. As best seen in FIG. 21, a cross-sectional area of the excess fluid passageway 1126 continuously increases moving in a direction from the collection trough 1201 to a distal end 1111 of the housing 1100. This occurs in the exemplified embodiment due to the outer annular wall 1101 being angled/inclined whereas the first inner annular wall 1120 is vertical. By varying the cross-sectional area of the excess fluid passageway 1126 in this way, any excess fluid flowing therethrough is forced to the floor 1127 and through the openings 1128 therein so that it can flow into the collection trough 1201 below. This flow of the excess amounts of the bubble solution will be described in greater detail below with reference to FIGS. 21, 33A, and 33B.

Referring to FIGS. 20, 21, 25A and 25B, the bubble solution dispenser 1400 and the support member 1450 will be described in greater detail. In the exemplified embodiment, the support member 1450 is pivotably coupled to the bubble solution dispenser 1400. Thus, the support member 1450 can be pivoted or rotated relative to the bubble solution dispenser 1400 (and relative to the housing 1100 because the bubble solution dispenser 1400 is fixedly coupled to the housing 1100 in the exemplified embodiment) about an axis E-E that is perpendicular to and non-coplanar with the longitudinal axis D-D of the housing 1100. Specifically, the support member 1450 is pivotable relative to the bubble solution dispenser 1400 and relative to the housing 1100 between a non-dispensing position, shown in FIG. 25A, and a dispensing position, shown in FIG. 25B.

As noted previously and discussed in more detail below, the support member 1450 is configured to support a container of the bubble solution. Thus, when the support member 1450 is in the non-dispensing position and is supporting the container, the container is in a substantially upright orientation such that it is prevented from dispensing the bubble solution into the bubble solution dispenser 1400. When the support member 1450 is in the dispensing position and is supporting the container, the container is in a substantially upside-down orientation such that it dispenses the bubble solution contained therein into the bubble solution dispenser 1400. This will be described in greater detail below with reference to at least FIGS. 21 and 29.

As noted previously, the bubble solution dispenser 1400 comprises a main body portion 1401 and a delivery member 1410. The main body portion 1401 comprises a floor 1402 and a sidewall 1403 extending upwardly from the floor 1402 to define a holding reservoir 1404. Furthermore, in the exemplified embodiment the bubble solution dispenser 1400 comprises a switch 1415 located along the sidewall 1403 of the main body portion 1401 (the switch 1415 is visible in FIGS. 20 and 21). In other embodiments, the switch 1415 could be located on the floor 1402 or at other locations without affecting the functionality of the apparatus 1000. In some embodiments, the switch 1415 may be the only switch provided on the apparatus 1000 for powering the motor 1300. Thus, the switch 1415 may be alterable between an open state in which the power source 1550 is not operably coupled to the motor 1300 (i.e., a circuit between the power source 1550 and the motor 1300 is open) and a closed state in which the power source 1550 is operably coupled to the motor 1300 to cause the motor 1300 to rotate about the rotational axis as described herein. Specifically, when the switch 1415 is in the open state the motor 1300 is not powered and when the switch 1415 is in the closed stat the motor 1300 is powered. Thus, the switch 1415 operates as a power button for the apparatus 1000. As noted above, in the exemplified embodiment the switch 1415 is the only power button on the apparatus 1000, and thus actuation of the switch 1415 is required to operate the apparatus 1000 and is the only manner in which the apparatus 1000 may be powered on.

In the exemplified embodiment, the switch 1415 is a momentary-type switch. Thus, the switch 1415 is biased into an open state such that no power is transmitted from the power source 1550 to the motor 1300. Stated another way, the switch 1415 is normally open and is only closed when the switch 1415 is being actuated or engaged or pressed. In a momentary-type switch, a force must be applied onto the switch to close the switch and supply power to the motor 1300 and a cessation or release of the force causes the switch 1415 to bias back into the open (or off) state. Thus, in the exemplified embodiment when a force is applied onto the switch 1415 power is transmitted to the motor 1300 and when no force is applied onto the switch 1415 no power is transmitted to the motor 1300. Of course, in other embodiments the switch 1415 may be an alternate action switch (such as a flip switch, a toggle switch, or the like), whereby the switch must be “flipped” to be altered into a continuous on/off state. In such embodiments, in one position of the switch the switch is closed and power is transmitted to the motor 1300 an in another position of the switch the switch is open and no power is transmitted to the motor 1300. While both different types of switches may be used, in the exemplary embodiment the switch 1415 is a momentary-type switch and it is biased into the open state (i.e., a normally open momentary-type switch) such that no power is transmitted from the power source 1550 to the motor 1300 unless a force is applied onto the switch 1415 to actuate the switch 1415 into the closed state.

The support member 1450 comprises an upstanding wall 1451 having a front opening 1452 through which a container of bubble solution may be passed. The upstanding wall 1451 has an arcuate shape but extends for only part of a ring or loop, thereby leaving the front opening 1452 open. The upstanding wall 1451 comprises an inner surface 1453 that defines a support cavity 1454 within which a portion of the container 1500 of bubble solution can be supported. Furthermore, there is a ledge 1455 extending from the inner surface 1453 of the upstanding wall 1451 into the support cavity 1454 for purposes of supporting the container 1500. In the exemplified embodiment, the ledge 1455 comprises a plurality of spaced apart ledge segments, although a singular continuous ledge member could be used in other embodiments. When the container 1500 is supported by the support member 1450, a protrusion on the neck of the container 1500 is typically supported atop of the ledge 1455 as best shown in FIG. 21. Furthermore, the upstanding wall 1451 is somewhat flexible, such that it flexes outwardly as the container 1500 is being inserted into the support cavity 1454 and then snaps back into a tight fit against the container 1500 to hold it in place.

The support member 1450 further comprises an actuation member 1460 that is configured to actuate the switch 1415 on the bubble solution dispenser 1450 when the support member 1450 is in the dispensing position shown in FIG. 25B. In the exemplified embodiment, the actuation member 1460 comprises a flexible tab 1461 that is formed by a U-shaped slit 1462 extending through the upstanding wall 1451. Thus, the flexible tab 1461 is able to flex inwardly into the support cavity 1454 and outwardly away from the support cavity 1454 in response to forces acting thereon. In the exemplified embodiment, the flexible tab 1461 comprises a body portion 1463, a first tab portion 1464 that protrudes from an inner surface of the upstanding wall 1453 and into the support cavity 1454, and a second tab portion 1465 that protrudes from an outer surface of the upstanding wall 1453 in a direction away from the support cavity 1454. In some embodiments, the switch 1415 and the actuation member 1460 may be collectively referred to herein as an actuation assembly.

As described in greater detail below, when the container 1500 is being supported by the support member 1450, the container 1500 contacts the first tab portion 1464 of the flexible tab 1461 and flexes the flexible tab 1461 radially outward in a direction away from the support cavity 1454. Specifically because the first tab portion 1464 protrudes into the support cavity 1454, when the container 1500 is disposed within the support cavity 1454 the container 1500 contacts the first tab portion 1464 and presses it outwardly. This causes the second tab portion 1465 to extend further from the outer surface of the upstanding wall 1455. Thus, when there is no container in the support cavity 1454, the flexible tab 1461 is in its biased state whereby the second portion 1465 of the flexible tab 1461 extends a first distance from an outer surface of the upstanding wall 1451. When the container 1500 is located in the support cavity 1454 and supported by the support member 1450, the flexible tab 1461 is flexed outwardly so that the second portion 1465 of the flexible tab 1461 extends a second distance from the outer surface of the upstanding wall 1451, with the second distance being greater than the first distance.

In the exemplified embodiment, the outward flexing of the flexible tab 1461 when the container 1500 is being supported by the support member 1450 is what causes the flexible tab 1461 of the actuation member 1460 to actuate the switch 1415. Specifically, in some embodiments when the support member 1450 is not supporting a container, putting the support member 1450 into the dispensing position will not result in the actuation member 1460 actuating the switch 1415. This is because in such embodiments when the container 1500 is not supported by the support member 1450, the second portion 1465 of the flexible tab 1461 does not protrude far enough from the upstanding wall 1451 to engage the switch 1415. However, when the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500, putting the support member 1450 into the dispensing position will result in the actuation member 1460 actuating the switch 1415. Specifically, because the second portion 1465 of the flexible tab 1461 extends further from the upstanding wall 1451 when the container 1500 is located in the support cavity 1454, the second portion 1465 of the flexible tab 1461 is able to contact/engage the switch 1415 with a sufficient force to actuate the switch 1415 and power the apparatus 1000 on.

Thus, in some embodiments the apparatus 1000 is only powered on when: (1) the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 and the support member 1450 is in the dispensing position; or (2) a user manually presses the switch 1415. However, because the switch 1415 is a momentary type switch in the exemplified embodiment, requiring a user to have a continuous hold on the switch 1415 during operation is undesirable. Thus, having the support member 1450 achieve the actuation of the switch 1415 is desirable. This also ensures that any time the container 1500 is supported by the support member 1450 in the dispensing position so it is dispensing the bubble solution into the bubble solution dispenser 1400, the apparatus 1000 is powered on, thereby preventing the bubble solution from simply flowing into the housing 1100 during times of non-operation. To state it succinctly, anytime that the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 in the dispensing position (e.g., FIGS. 25B, 28, and 29), the switch 1415 will be actuated into the closed state and power will be transmitted from the power source 1550 to the motor 1300.

Turning to FIGS. 26A and 26B, illustrations are provided showing the container 1500 being inserted into the support cavity 1454 of the support member 1450. Specifically, the container 1500 is inserted through the front opening 1452 in the upstanding wall 1451. As the container 1500 is so inserted, the upstanding wall 1451 may flex slightly to enable the container 1500 to be fully inserted into the support cavity 1454. Furthermore, once the container 1500 is snapped into the support cavity 1454, the container 1500 presses on the flexible tab 1461 of the actuation member 1460 and pushes the second tab portion 1465 thereof outwardly, as shown by the arrow in FIG. 26B.

Next, referring to FIGS. 20, 21, and 27, the apparatus 1000 is illustrated in a perspective view and various cross-sectional views with the support member 1450 in the non-dispensing position. The support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 as previously described and shown in FIGS. 20 and 21. As noted, when the support member 1450 is in the non-dispensing position, the bubble solution container 1500 is substantially upright. As used herein, the term substantially upright indicates a position whereby the bubble solution container 1500 cannot dispense the bubble solution contained therein by gravity alone. Thus, the term substantially upright may be somewhat dependent on the amount of bubble solution contained therein, because a container can be tilted more without spilling its contents when it contains a lower volume of the contents. In some embodiments, the term “substantially upright” includes the container 1500 being oriented so that its longitudinal axis F-F is at an angle of between 45° and 135° relative to a horizontal plane with its top dispensing end 1502 facing away from a ground surface (the ground surface being any surface upon which the apparatus 1000 is resting during normal use and operation of the apparatus 1000).

As seen in FIGS. 20, 21, and 27, when the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 in the non-dispensing position, the switch 1415 is not being actuated. Thus, in embodiments whereby the switch 1415 is a momentary switch, the switch 1415 is in its “off” state or open state such that no power is being transmitted from the power source 1550 to the motor 1300. Similar results can be achieved when the switch 1415 is an alternate action switch.

Referring to FIGS. 28-30, the apparatus 1000 is illustrated in a perspective view and various cross-sectional views with the support member 1450 supporting the container 1500 and being in the dispensing position. In the exemplified embodiment, the support member 1450 is pivotably coupled to the bubble solution dispenser 1400. Thus, in the exemplified embodiment altering the support member 1450 from the non-dispensing position to the dispensing position comprises rotating or pivoting the support member 1450 about the axis E-E. Of course, in other embodiments the support member 1450 may be slidably coupled to the bubble solution dispenser 1400 so as to be slid between the dispensing and non-dispensing positions. In still other embodiments, the support member 1450 may not be attached to the bubble solution dispenser 1400 at all, but may instead simply be placed into the holding reservoir 1404 when desired for use.

When the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 and altered into the dispensing position, the bubble solution 1501 begins to flow out of the container 1500 and into the holding reservoir 1404 of the bubble solution dispenser and from the holding reservoir 1404 into the delivery reservoir 1413 of the delivery member 1410. This is because the container 1500 is in an upside-down or substantially upside-down orientation whereby a dispensing end of the container 1500 is facing downward. The container 1500 need not be completely vertical and upside-down, but rather needs to be positioned and oriented in such a manner that the bubble solution 1501 will readily flow out of the container 1500 and into the holding reservoir 1404.

From the delivery reservoir 1413, the bubble solution flows out of the slit 1414 and onto the bubble generating devices 1321 of the bubble generating assembly 1320. Furthermore, when the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 in the dispensing position, the motor 1300 is operating and rotating. Thus, the fan device 1310 and the bubble generating assembly 1320 are also rotating about a rotational axis R2-R2 due to their operable coupling to the motor 1300. Thus, as the bubble solution becomes loaded on the bubble generating devices 1321, the bubble generating devices 1321 rotate into alignment with the air flow passageway 1125 so that the air stream generated by the fan device 1310 blows through the bubble generating devices 1321 and converts the bubble solution into bubbles.

As noted above, when the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 and is in the dispensing position, the switch 1415 is automatically actuated into the closed state and the motor 1300 is powered. In the exemplified embodiment, this occurs as follows. When the support member 1450 is altered, pivoted, rotated, or the like into the dispensing position, the second tab portion 1465 of the flexible tab 1461 contacts the switch 1415 and presses against the switch 1415. This pressure/force applied onto the switch 1414 alters the switch 1415 from its biased/normal open state to a closed state, which in turn causes power from the power source 1550 to be transmitted to the motor 1300. As noted above, the container 1500 is in contact with the first tab portion 1464 of the flexible tab 1461, which prevents the flexible tab 1461 from simply flexing away from the switch 1415 but instead ensures that the second portion 1465 of the flexible tab 1461 will contact the switch 1415 with sufficient force to actuate the switch 1415 into the closed state. Thus, anytime the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 and is altered into the dispensing position, the switch 1415 will be actuated into the closed state to supply power from the power source 1550 to the motor 1300 to initiate operation of the apparatus 1000. This ensures bubble solution is not flowing out of the container 1500 and into the apparatus 1000 without the apparatus 1000 and motor 1300 being powered on.

It should be noted that opposite motion/movement of the support member 1450 relative to the bubble solution dispenser 1400 has the opposite effect in that it alters the switch 1415 from the closed state (i.e., on state) to the open state (i.e., off state). Specifically, in the exemplified embodiment, altering or pivoting the support member 1450 from the dispensing position to the non-dispensing position will remove contact between the actuation member 1460 and the switch 1415, which will cause the switch 1415 to alter into the open state (when the switch 1415 is a momentary-type switch). In other embodiments where the switch 1415 is an alternate action switch, the action of moving the support member 1450 from the dispensing position to the non-dispensing position will toggle the switch 1415 (rather than simply removing force from being applied onto the switch) to alter the switch 1415 from the closed state to the open state. In either case, altering/pivoting the support member 1450 from the dispensing position (FIG. 30) to the non-dispensing position (FIG. 28) will alter the switch from the closed state (on state) to the open state (off state) so that power is no longer transmitted from the power source 1550 to the motor 1300.

Referring to FIGS. 31A, 31B, and 32, operation of the apparatus 1000 to generate bubbles will be described. In FIGS. 31A and 31B, the support member 1450 is supporting or holding the container 1500 with the container 1500 containing a supply of the bubble solution 1501 and the support member 1450 is in the dispensing position. Thus, the bubble solution 1501 flows out of the container 1500 and into the holding reservoir 1404 and from the holding reservoir 1404 into the dispensing reservoir 1413. From the dispensing reservoir 1413, the bubble solution 1501 flows through the slit 1414 where it is dispensed onto the bubble generating devices 1321 of the bubble generating assembly 1320. Furthermore, as noted above, when the support member 1450 is supporting the container 1500 and is in the dispensing position, the switch 1415 is actuated into the closed state. Thus, as the bubble solution 1501 is being dispensed onto the bubble generating devices 1321, the bubble generating devices 1321 (and the bubble generating assembly 1320 as a whole) is rotating about the rotational axis R2-R2 and the fan device 1310 is rotating about the rotational axis R2-R2. Thus, the bubble generating devices 1321 rotate into alignment with the delivery member 1410 of the bubble solution dispenser 1400 to become loaded with the bubble solution 1501(see, for example, FIG. 32) and then continue to rotate into alignment with the air flow passageway 1125 so that the air stream generated by the fan device 1310 can pass through the bubble generating devices 1321 and generate bubbles 1505 from the bubble solution 1501 loaded thereon.

As seen in FIGS. 31A and 31B, as the above operation is taking place, excess amounts of the bubble solution 1501 is falling into the collection trough 1201 of the drip tray 1200. Specifically, a continuous flow of the bubble solution 1501 is made to flow through the slit 1414 in the delivery member 1410 of the bubble solution dispenser 1400. Furthermore, the bubble generating devices 1321 are arranged in a circumferentially spaced apart manner such that there are gaps between adjacent ones of the bubble generating devices 1321. Thus, a portion of the bubble solution 1501 will be dispensed from the delivery member 1410 of the bubble solution dispenser 1400 but will not be loaded onto one of the bubble generating devices 1321. Instead, this portion of the bubble solution 1501 will be collected in the collection reservoir 1201 of the drip tray 1200 so that it can be poured back into the container 1500 for re-use.

Referring to FIGS. 29, 33A, and 33B, the flow of the excess amounts of the bubble solution 1501 that are dispensed from the delivery member 1410 but not loaded onto any of the bubble generating members 1321 will be described. The housing 1100 comprises at least one funneling reservoir 1160 located between the first and second inner annular walls 1120, 1130. In the exemplified embodiment, there are two of the funneling reservoirs 1160. Specifically, the housing 1100 comprises a raised platform 1150 directly beneath the delivery member 1410 and one of the funneling reservoirs 1160 on either side of the raised platform 1150. The raised platform 1150, the funneling reservoirs 1160, and the air flow passageway 1125 are collectively arranged along a loop or ring extending between the first and second inner annular walls 1120, 1130. Thus, the funneling reservoirs 1160 and the air flow passageway 1125 are located along a reference cylinder or a reference ring that is located between the first and second inner annular walls 1120, 1130.

Each of the funneling reservoirs 1160 is defined between a portion of the first inner annular wall 1120, a portion of the second inner annular wall 1130, a first upstanding wall 1161 extending between the first and second inner annular walls 1120, 1130, and a second upstanding wall 1162 extending between the first and second inner annular walls 1120, 1130. The first and second upstanding walls 1161, 1162 are circumferentially spaced apart from one another. Furthermore, there is an aperture 1163 in the portion of the first inner annular wall 1120 that bounds the funneling reservoir 1160. The aperture 1163 forms a passageway through the first inner annular wall 1120 from the funneling reservoir 1160 to the excess fluid passageway 1126.

Thus, as shown in FIG. 33A, the bubble solution 1501 is dispensed from the slit 1414 in the delivery member 1410 onto the raised platform 1150. The bubble solution 1501 then flows down to the funneling reservoirs 1160, through the aperture 1163 in the portion of the first inner annular wall 1120, and into the excess fluid passageway 1126. Referring to FIGS. 29 and 33B, the bubble solution 1501 then flows downwardly within the excess fluid passageway 1126 and through the openings 1128 in the floor 1127 of the excess fluid passageway 1126. Once it flows through the openings 1128, the excess bubble solution 1501 contacts and flows along the inclined drainage surfaces 1207 and then into the collection trough 1201 of the drip tray 1200. If any of the excess bubble solution 1501 flows onto the distal surface 1205 of the drainage member 1204, it will flow downwardly towards the air flow passageways 1106 and down along the inclined drainage surfaces 1207. The distal surface 1205 of the drainage member 1204 may be inclined from a centerpoint to an outer edge to facilitate this flow direction for the excess bubble solution.

Referring to FIGS. 34A and 34B, an alternative mechanism for actuating the switch 1415 will be described. In FIGS. 34A and 34B, the apparatus 1000 is exactly as has been described above, except the support member 1450 may be omitted. In this embodiment the container 1500 containing the bubble solution can simply be placed upside-down into the holding reservoir 1404 of the bubble solution dispenser 1400 instead of it being held by the support member 1450 and pivoted into position. Because the support member 1450 is not used in this embodiment, the actuation member 1460 may not be used to actuate the switch 1415. Rather, in this embodiment the container 1500 comprises an actuation member 1560 thereon. The actuation member 1560 may be formed as an integral part of the container 1500 or it may be formed on a collar or lid that is coupled to the container 1500. In any case, when the container 1500 is placed in an upside-down orientation within the holding reservoir 1404 of the bubble solution dispenser 1400, the actuation member 1560 will engage and actuate the switch 1415 in the same manner as this was accomplished by the actuation member 1460 in the previously described embodiment. This will cause the apparatus 1000 to operate with various features rotating as noted above. The bubble solution dispenser 1400 and/or the container 1500 may also have alignment features in this embodiment to ensure that the container 1500 is positioned in an appropriate orientation so that the actuation member 1560 engages the switch 1415.

As used throughout, ranges are used as shorthand for describing each and every value that is within the range. Any value within the range can be selected as the terminus of the range. In addition, all references cited herein are hereby incorporated by referenced in their entireties. In the event of a conflict in a definition in the present disclosure and that of a cited reference, the present disclosure controls.

While the invention has been described with respect to specific examples including presently preferred modes of carrying out the invention, those skilled in the art will appreciate that there are numerous variations and permutations of the above described systems and techniques. It is to be understood that other embodiments may be utilized and structural and functional modifications may be made without departing from the scope of the present invention. Thus, the spirit and scope of the invention should be construed broadly as set forth in the appended claims.

claim.claim-text: 1. An apparatus for generating bubbles comprising:a longitudinal axis;a first housing assembly containing a fan device and a bubble generating assembly;a second housing assembly containing a power source and a motor that are operably coupled together, the second housing assembly comprising a second connection post having a distal end with an opening, a drive shaft of the motor protruding through the opening in the distal end of the second connection post;a drip tray comprising a floor and a sidewall that define a collection reservoir, a third connection post protruding from the floor to a distal end, the third connection post having a hollow interior; andwherein the first housing assembly, the drip tray, and the second housing assembly are slidably coupled together with the drip tray located axially in between the first and second housing assemblies, the second connection post of the second housing assembly nesting within the hollow interior of the third connection post of the drip tray such that the drive shaft of the motor protrudes through an opening in the distal end of the third connection post and through an opening in a bottom end of the first housing assembly to operably couple the drive shaft of the motor to the fan device.

2. The apparatus according to claim 1 further comprising:the first housing assembly comprising a first connection post having a hollow interior, each of the first, second, and third connection posts being located along the longitudinal axis; andwherein the third connection post of the drip tray nests within the hollow interior of the first connection post of the first housing assembly.

3. The apparatus according to claim 2 wherein the first, second, and third connection posts are arranged in an overlapping configuration such that an axis transverse to the longitudinal axis intersects each of the first, second, and third connection posts.

4. The apparatus according to claim 2 further comprising:the second housing assembly comprising a base portion having a top surface and the second connection post extending from the top surface of the base portion, the second connection post comprising an outer surface having a second alignment feature;the first housing assembly comprising a main body having the bottom end and the first connection post extending from the bottom end of the main body, a distal end of the first connection post comprising a first alignment feature;the third connection post of the drip tray comprising an inner surface having a third alignment feature and an outer surface having a fourth alignment feature; andwherein the first and fourth alignment features mate with one another to facilitate coupling of the first housing assembly to the drip tray and wherein the second and third alignment features mate with one another to facilitate coupling of the second housing assembly to the drip tray.

5. The apparatus according to claim 1 wherein the sidewall and the third connection post of the drip tray extend upwardly from the floor in the same direction, and wherein the sidewall has a first height and the third connection post has a second height, the second height being greater than the first height.

6. The apparatus according to claim 1 wherein the second connection post comprises an outer surface having a second alignment feature and the third connection post comprises an inner surface having a third alignment feature, the second and third alignment features mating with one another to facilitate proper alignment of the drip tray relative to the second housing assembly.

7. The apparatus according to claim 1 wherein the first housing assembly, the drip tray, and the second housing assembly are coupled together solely by gravity without any mechanical fasteners such that the apparatus is disassembled by lifting the first housing assembly vertically relative to the drip tray and the second housing assembly and then lifting the drip tray vertically relative to the second housing assembly.

8. The apparatus according to claim 1 wherein the first housing assembly comprises a bubble solution dispenser comprising a bubble solution reservoir, wherein the fan device is operably coupled to the bubble solution dispenser by a gear train so that the fan device and the bubble solution dispenser are simultaneously rotated about the rotational axis by the motor, and wherein the fan device rotates at a first rotational velocity and the bubble solution dispenser rotates at a second rotational velocity, the first rotational velocity being greater than the second rotational velocity, wherein the bubble solution reservoir contains a supply of a bubble solution, and wherein during rotation the bubble solution dispenser loads the bubble solution onto bubble generating devices of the bubble generating assembly so that bubbles can be generated as an air stream generated by the fan device passes through the bubble generating devices that are loaded with the bubble solution, wherein the bubble generating assembly is stationary while the bubble solution dispenser rotates to deliver the bubble solution to the bubble generating assembly

9. The apparatus according to any one of claims 1 wherein all electrical components of the apparatus are located within the second housing assembly which is sealed against the ingress of liquid into the interior cavity.

10. The apparatus according to claim 1 wherein an outer surface of the drip tray is flush with an outer surface of the second housing assembly, a bottom surface of the drip tray is in surface contact with a top surface of the second housing assembly.

11. The apparatus according to claim 1 wherein the bottom end of the first housing assembly is spaced apart from a top edge of the drip tray by a gap so that air can flow into the first housing assembly through the bottom end of the first housing assembly during rotation of the fan device.

12. An apparatus for generating bubbles comprising:a motor;a fan device operably coupled to the motor to generate an air stream;a bubble generating assembly comprising a plurality of bubble generating devices that are aligned with the air stream generated by the fan device;a bubble solution dispenser comprising a delivery reservoir having a floor with at least one aperture therein, the bubble solution dispenser containing a bubble solution; andwherein the motor is operably coupled to one of the bubble generating assembly or the bubble solution dispenser to cause relative rotation between the bubble generating assembly and the bubble solution dispenser during which the bubble solution falls through the at least one aperture in the floor of the delivery reservoir to load the bubble generating devices with the bubble solution, and wherein bubbles are generated as the air stream passes the bubble generating devices that are loaded with the bubble solution.

13. The apparatus according to claim 12 wherein the motor is operably coupled to the bubble solution dispenser to rotate the bubble solution dispenser, and wherein the bubble generating assembly is stationary.

14. The apparatus according to claim 13 wherein the bubble solution dispenser comprises a hub portion comprising a storage reservoir and a delivery member comprising the delivery reservoir, wherein the bubble solution is held in the storage reservoir of the hub portion and is only permitted to flow to the delivery reservoir of the delivery member during rotation of the bubble solution dispenser.

15. The apparatus according to claim 14 wherein the storage reservoir comprises a floor having a first circumferential portion and a second circumferential portion, the second circumferential portion extending from the first circumferential portion to a terminal end and being inclined relative to the first circumferential portion.
16. The apparatus according to claim 15 wherein the first circumferential portion is oriented along a horizontal plane and the second circumferential portion forms a ramp.
17. The apparatus according to claim 12 wherein the at least one delivery member lies in a plane that does not intersect any of the bubble generating devices.

18. An apparatus for generating bubbles comprising:a power source;a motor;a switch alterable between an open state in which the power source is not operably coupled to the motor and the motor is static and a closed state in which the power source is operably coupled to the motor and the motor rotates about a rotational axis;a fan device operably coupled to the motor so that the fan device generates an air stream when the switch is in the closed state;a bubble generating assembly comprising at least one bubble generating device that is aligned with the air stream generated by the fan device, the bubble generating assembly coupled to the motor so that the bubble generating device rotates about the rotational axis when the switch is in the closed state;a bubble solution dispenser comprising at least one delivery member for loading a bubble solution onto the at least one bubble generating device, the bubble solution dispenser configured to hold a container of bubble solution in an upside-down orientation so that the bubble solution in the container is dispensed into the bubble solution dispenser; andwherein when the bubble solution dispenser is holding the container of bubble solution in the upside-down orientation, the switch is automatically actuated into the closed state.
